name: disorder
content:
disorder

noun
 
 
/dɪsˈɔːdə(r)/
 
/dɪsˈɔːrdər/
jump to other results
  1. ​
     
    [countable, uncountable] (medical) a condition or illness that causes problems with the way part of the body or brain works
    • a blood/bowel disorder
    • He was diagnosed with an anxiety disorder.
    • This is a rare disorder of the liver.
    • help for people with alcohol use disorder
    see also attention deficit disorder, autism spectrum disorder, bipolar disorder, body dysmorphic disorder, borderline personality disorder, dissociative identity disorder, eating disorder, multiple personality disorder, narcissistic personality disorder, obsessive compulsive disorder, personality disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, seasonal affective disorder, split personality disorder, substance use disorder
    Synonyms diseasedisease
    • illness
    • disorder
    • infection
    • condition
    • ailment
    • bug
    These are all words for a medical problem.
    • disease a medical problem affecting humans, animals or plants, often caused by infection:
      • He suffers from a rare blood disease.
    • illness a medical problem, or a period of suffering from one:
      • She died after a long illness.
    disease or illness?Disease is used to talk about more severe medical problems, especially specific conditions and those that affect particular organs: Crohn's/​Parkinson's disease • heart/​kidney/​liver disease • heart/​kidney/​liver illness. Illness is used more generally and can refer to both severe and minor medical problems, and problems that affect mental health: a terminal/​life-threatening illness • a mild/​minor illness • mental illness • mental disease. Illness can be used about a period of time: a long/​short illness • a long/​short disease
    • disorder (rather formal) a condition that causes problems with the way part of the body or brain works:
      • a rare disorder of the liver.
      A disorder is generally not infectious. Disorder is often used in the names of specific conditions affecting the brain, for example attention deficit disorder, bipolar disorder or post-traumatic stress disorder. When it is used to talk about physical problems, it is often used with autoimmune, blood, bowel and kidney, and these are commonly serious, severe or rare.
    • infection an illness that is caused by bacteria or a virus and that affects one part of the body:
      • a throat infection
    • condition a medical problem that you have for a long time because it is not possible to cure it:
      • a heart condition
    • ailment (rather formal) an illness that is not very serious:
      • childhood ailments
    • bug (informal) an infectious illness that is usually fairly mild:
      • a stomach bug
    Patterns
    • to have/​suffer from a(n) disease/​illness/​disorder/​infection/​condition/​ailment/​bug
    • to catch/​contract/​get/​pick up a(n) disease/​illness/​infection/​bug
    Extra Examples
    • Consumption of fatty acids may help prevent the disorder.
    • Her doctor diagnosed a thyroid disorder.
    • She has a rare blood disorder.
    • people with rheumatoid arthritis, lupus and other autoimmune disorders
    • He is thought to have had a genetic disorder that stopped him from growing when he was young.
    • neurological disorders such as multiple sclerosis, epilepsy and Parkinson's disease
    • Insomnia is one of the most common sleep disorders.
    • The team says alcohol use disorder is a chronic disease.
    • Adolescents with mental disorders are waiting too long to get help.
    • Some people develop psychological disorders as a result of trauma.
    • disorders of the digestive system
    • She's got some kind of bowel disorder.
    Topics Health problemsb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • serious
    • severe
    • chronic
    • …
    verb + disorder
    • have
    • suffer from
    • develop
    • …
    disorder + verb
    • affect something
    preposition
    • disorder of
    See full entry
  2. ​
     
    [uncountable] (formal) an untidy state; a lack of order or organization
    • The room was in a state of disorder.
    • in (…) disorder His financial affairs were in complete disorder.
    • Everyone began shouting at once and the meeting broke up in disorder.
    opposite order
    Extra Examples
    • The country was thrown into disorder by the strikes.
    • He died suddenly, leaving his financial affairs in complete disorder.
    • He loves tidying up, making order out of disorder.
    • The gang of men scattered in disorder.
    • The world's currency markets were thrown into disorder.
    • the wild disorder of her red hair
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • complete
    verb + disorder
    • throw something into
    preposition
    • in disorder
    phrases
    • a state of disorder
    See full entry
  3. ​
     
    [uncountable] (formal) violent behaviour of large groups of people
    • an outbreak of rioting and public disorder
    • Twenty people were arrested after a night of civil disorder.
    compare order
    Extra Examples
    • The initiative aims to tackle alcohol-related disorder in towns.
    • The police will not tolerate disorder of any kind on our streets.
    • There have been outbreaks of serious public disorder.
    • Troops were sent in to quell the disorder.
    • new restrictions aimed at preventing social disorder
    • problems of youth disorder in our cities
    • the pressures on police caused by drink-related disorder
    • The food crisis led to outbreaks of rioting and public disorder.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • serious
    • widespread
    • violent
    • …
    … of disorder
    • outbreak
    verb + disorder
    • create
    • lead to
    • quell
    • …
    See full entry
    4. Word Originlate 15th cent. (as a verb): alteration, influenced by order, of earlier disordain, from Old French desordener, ultimately based on Latin ordinare ‘ordain’.

name: bipolar disorder
content:
bipolar disorder

noun
 
/ˌbaɪˈpəʊlə dɪsɔːdə(r)/
 
/ˌbaɪˈpəʊlər dɪsɔːrdər/
(also bipolar affective disorder)
[uncountable, countable]
(also old-fashioned manic depression [uncountable])
(psychology)
jump to other results
  1. ​a mental illness in which somebody has periods of time when they feel extremely depressed and tired and other periods when they feel extremely active and excited with a lot of energy
    Wordfinder
    • anorexia
    • autism
    • bipolar disorder
    • condition
    • dementia
    • depression
    • paranoia
    • psychosis
    • schizophrenia
    Topics Mental healthc2

name: eating disorder
content:
eating disorder

noun
 
/ˈiːtɪŋ dɪsɔːdə(r)/
 
/ˈiːtɪŋ dɪsɔːrdər/
jump to other results
  1. ​a condition in which somebody develops eating habits that are not healthy as a way of dealing with difficult feelings or situationsTopics Mental healthb2, Cooking and eatingb2

name: personality disorder
content:
personality disorder

noun
 
/ˌpɜːsəˈnæləti dɪsɔːdə(r)/
 
/ˌpɜːrsəˈnæləti dɪsɔːrdər/
 (psychology)
jump to other results
  1. ​a condition in which somebody thinks, feels and behaves very differently from most other people in a way that causes them to have serious difficulties in their life and in their relationships with other people see also borderline personality disorderTopics Mental healthc1
See personality disorder in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee personality disorder in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English

name: substance use disorder
content:
substance use disorder

noun
 
/ˈsʌbstəns juːs dɪsɔːdə(r)/
 
/ˈsʌbstəns juːs dɪsɔːrdər/
 [countable, uncountable] (medical)
jump to other results
  1. ​a condition which makes somebody likely to take too much of a harmful drug or drink too much alcohol, and to be unable to stop
    • You may have a loved one who struggles with a substance use disorder.
    • treatment for substance use disorder
    Extra Examples
    • They found that 64% of homeless adults in the region have a serious mental illness and 24% have a substance use disorder.
    • The risk of addiction to the medication is higher if you have a substance use disorder.
    • Familes and friends are also affected by substance use disorder.
    • Substance use disorder, otherwise known as addiction, can be devastating.
    • The film follows her as she tries to cope with her substance use disorder.
    • The centre is a referral service for substance use disorder treatment.
    Topics Health problemsc2, Social issuesc2
Check pronunciation: substance use disorder

name: attention deficit disorder
content:
attention deficit disorder

noun
 
/əˌtenʃn ˈdefɪsɪt dɪsɔːdə(r)/
 
/əˌtenʃn ˈdefɪsɪt dɪsɔːrdər/
(also attention deficit hyperactivity disorder)
[uncountable]
(abbreviation ADD, ADHD)
jump to other results
  1. ​a condition, usually beginning in childhood, that makes it difficult for somebody to pay attention and concentrate, and may make it difficult for them to control their behaviourTopics Mental healthc2
Check pronunciation: attention deficit disorder

name: autism spectrum disorder
content:
autism spectrum disorder

noun
 
/ˌɔːtɪzəm ˈspektrəm dɪsɔːdə(r)/
 
/ˌɔːtɪzəm ˈspektrəm dɪsɔːrdər/
 [countable, uncountable] (medical)
(also autism [uncountable])
(abbreviation ASD)
jump to other results
  1. ​a range of conditions affecting brain development that can be severe or mild, or any one of these conditions. People with autism spectrum disorder can find it difficult to communicate and form relationships, and may show repeated or limited patterns of thought and behaviour.
    • support for families with children who have autism spectrum disorder
    • He was diagnosed with an autistic spectrum disorder.
    Topics Disabilityc2
Check pronunciation: autism spectrum disorder

name: body dysmorphic disorder
content:
body dysmorphic disorder

noun
 
/ˌbɒdi dɪsˈmɔːfɪk dɪsɔːdə(r)/
 
/ˌbɑːdi dɪsˈmɔːrfɪk dɪsɔːrdər/
(also body dysmorphia
 
/ˌbɒdi dɪsˈmɔːfiə/
 
/ˌbɑːdi dɪsˈmɔːrfiə/
)
[uncountable]
(abbreviation BDD)
(psychology)
jump to other results
  1. ​a mental illness that causes somebody to spend a lot of time worrying about problems with their appearance which may not exist or which others may not notice
    • He was diagnosed with body dysmorphic disorder after struggling with his body image for many years.
    Topics Mental healthc2
Check pronunciation: body dysmorphic disorder

name: seasonal affective disorder
content:
seasonal affective disorder

noun
 
/ˌsiːzənl əˈfektɪv dɪsɔːdə(r)/
 
/ˌsiːzənl əˈfektɪv dɪsɔːrdər/
 [uncountable]
(abbreviation SAD)
jump to other results
  1. ​a condition in which a person feels sad and tired during late autumn and winter when there is not much light from the sunTopics Mental healthc2
See seasonal affective disorder in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
